Today's meeting is to discuss the collection of farm plastics. I welcome the following witnesses from the Department of Climate, Energy and the Environment: Ms Bernie Kiely, principal officer; and Ms Danielle McCormack, assistant principal officer. We will also hear from the following witnesses from the Irish Farm Film Producers Group, IFFPG: Mr. Tom Dunne, chairperson; Mr. Liam Moloney, general manager; and Ms Geraldine O'Sullivan, co-secretary and director. Cuirim fáilte rompu go léir.
Copies of the witnesses' opening statements have been circulated to members but we will allow five minutes for opening comments, after which there will be an opportunity for questions and answers.
Since this is only one session, I propose that we take extra time for each speaker slot of ten minutes -----
Can the Chair let us back in?

If we do the ten minutes, then there is an opportunity for a second round of questions. I will not be excluding members. I want to give people the opportunity to ask as many questions as they feel appropriate and we will use the full time on it. Are members okay with that? Okay.

I thank the committee for giving us the opportunity to be here this afternoon to talk about farm plastics. One of the Department’s functions in relation to waste management is to set the policy and legislative framework for the extended producer responsibility, EPR, model in Ireland across the various waste streams. Ireland uses the EPR model for dealing with a number of waste streams, including farm plastics, tyres, end of life vehicles, packaging, electrical equipment and batteries. These schemes have been developed based on the producer pays principle. This is where producers have responsibility to finance the collection and environmentally sound management of their products at end of life. To date, these schemes have operated successfully and have assisted Ireland in reaching its domestic and EU recycling targets. Producer responsibility schemes operate under ministerial approval. The Department has oversight of the ministerial approval. Day-to-day operational matters are the responsibility of the schemes.

Ireland is one of a few countries in Europe to have introduced legislation specifically designed to promote the recycling of farm plastics. This legislation places a legal responsibility on producers of farm film products to specifically support recycling. The options open to producers placing farm film products on the Irish market are to either become directly involved in the recycling of farm plastics waste and operating a deposit and return scheme or to participate in an approved farm plastics recycling scheme. To date, producers have opted to meet their obligations in this respect by becoming members of a compliance scheme.

Under the legislation, the Irish Farm Film Producers Group Limited, IFFPG, operates further to an approval granted by the Minister as the national farm plastics recycling scheme. IFFPG has been doing so since 1998. The company is a not-for-profit body, which is owned by its producer members and the Irish Farmers’ Association. IFFPG’s current approval is due to expire at the end of 2025. It is open to producers to establish an alternative scheme at any time and seek ministerial approval under the regulations, should they wish to do so. The Department is not aware of interest by other groups in applying for ministerial approval.

Under the approved scheme, producers pay a producer recycling contribution to IFFPG based on the quantity of product they place on the market. The recycling contribution applies to all product based on the Irish market and, along with a collection fee for farmers set by IFFPG, is used to fund the collection, transportation and treatment of farm plastics. The role of the Department is oversight of IFFPG’s adherence to the terms of its approval. A mid-term review of IFFPG’s current approval was concluded in 2024 and the Department requested IFFPG to undertake a series of actions relating to the board, the contingency fund and enforcement matters. The Department is satisfied that IFFPG is engaging positively with the outcomes of the review and we continue to monitor same to ensure that the requirements set by it are fully implemented.

IFFPG is performing well in relation to its record of collection and recycling of farm plastic as set out in its annual report published on its website. The Department is supportive of IFFPG’s contribution to the environmental management of farm plastics.
Thank you.
There was also a letter - a reply from the Minister - issued earlier today that came to the committee. I am not sure whether the Chair received that.
It is received.
Okay. If anybody needs to know what was in the letter, I am happy to -----
We will be dealing with that under correspondence later.
Okay.
We need to know what was in the letter.
We would typically be getting our correspondence on Friday and we would deal with it the fortnight after.
That letter could influence proceedings here this evening.
I have not seen it. We have received it but I have not seen it.
Will Ms Kiely read it into the record now?
I second that.
One moment.

With Ms Kiely's agreement and that of the Chair, she can read it into the record of this meeting, as I think it may be relevant. We do not want to waste anyone's time. It would be Ms Kiely's decision and we would not be forcing anyone to do anything. If Ms Kiely and the Chair are agreeable, I think we should have it read into the record of the meeting now.
I support that. Agreed.
I am happy to read the body of the letter, subject to the official receipt of the letter through the committee.
Cathaoirleach,

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2025 in relation to the performance of Irish Farm Film Producers Group (IFFPG), which operates the waste farm plastics extended producer responsibility scheme under Ministerial Approval. I note that IFFPG and officials from the Department accepted the invitation to appear before your committee on 12 November. My response to your specific queries is set out below.
Mid-Term Review

As you are aware from correspondence issued to the Committee on 12 September 2025, IFFPG was provided with a list of recommendations further to the conclusion of the Mid-Term Review. The Department has been monitoring compliance with these recommendations and while it continues to prove challenging to build up the Contingency Fund, IFFPG has been engaging positively and constructively with all recommendations and I have provided an update on some key areas below.
- Annual training is being provided to IFFPG board members to support discharge of their functions. A comprehensive presentation to the board from its solicitor was delivered in May 2025.
- IFFPG has agreed an enforcement protocol with the Waste Enforcement Regional Lead Authorities (WERLAs), with an initial focus on targeting non-compliant retailers in the border region.
- IFFPG is developing an enforcement portal which is expected to be operational by the end of the year.
- IFFPG has approved scrutiny of product codes presented by farmers at bring centres.
- IFFPG has been successfully addressing the storage of legacy farm plastic waste at its contracted sites, and this is being monitored on a monthly basis by the WERLAs.
Contingency fund

IFFPG commissioned a business review of its operations, which was undertaken by IFAC. This was completed in March 2025 and makes recommendations across IFFPG’s areas of operation in the context of its challenging operational environment. As the report was commissioned by IFFPG, I have requested the group to provide you with the report.
Contract

The Waste Management (Farm Plastics) Regulations, 2001, state that a producer of farm plastics may self-comply with the Regulations by operating a deposit and return scheme, or they may join a collective compliance scheme to discharge their responsibilities under the Regulations. Any organisation representing producers may apply for approval to operate a scheme at any time, and once all required information has been provided, the application will be considered by the Department. A key issue for any producer responsibility organisation is support from industry, and therefore, it is a matter for the sector to initiate any such application.
IFFPG submitted its application for a further Ministerial Approval under the Waste Farm Plastics Regulations in July 2025.
I trust the above addresses the concerns of the Committee.
Yours sincerely,
Alan Dillon TD, Minister of State with responsibility for Circular Economy at the Department of Climate, Energy and the Environment

Just to clarify a point. Correspondence was issued on 12 November, which is today. It was to an email address: "JCAM". That is not the committee. The committee has not had an opportunity to consider it. The information within it is available.
It is now on the record.
Yes, and it will be made available to the committee and discussed in due course. We will move on to the second submission.

We are very happy to be here today. We have circulated an opening statement and the independent IFAC review of the scheme, which was carried out earlier this year. I am going to give a quick verbal overview of the opening statement to provide an idea of who we are, where we are coming from and what are currently focused on.

We were one of the first EPR schemes established in the country. We were established in 1998 by the key stakeholders, namely, the farm plastic producers, the companies that put farm plastic products on the market, and the IFA. As the committee has heard already, we are licensed for five-year periods by the Department of the environment. We are a not-for-profit company and our focus is on providing a comprehensive collection service to farmers and to exceed the national recycling targets as set by the Department of the environment for farm plastic waste. Our board is representative of the key stakeholders, the farm plastic producers and the IFA, as well as some independent directors. We are funded primarily by the recycling levy but also by a weight-based collection charge. That encourages farmers to bring in cleaner plastics to the bring centres.

As far as collecting the plastic goes, we collect through a network of approved contractors. They are selected following an open national tendering process that is typically held every five years. The most recent one was concluded at the beginning of this year and we currently have five approved contractors.

When it comes to results, what the scheme has achieved is hugely impressive by any standard. We have 100,000 farmer customers, so the vast majority of farmers in Ireland are engaging with the service. They engage with the service because it is convenient, cost effective and, above all, reliable. We are collecting and recycling virtually all plastic that is being put on the market by our members. We have a virtual 100% recycling rate. There is no other waste plastic stream in the country that comes anywhere close to this.

Everything has not been easy, however, in recent years. We have had to deal with a very difficult recycling market situation. That has come about because of global events such as war in Ukraine, Covid and, before that, a decision by the Chinese to stop importing plastic waste. That has resulted in a 600% increase in the cost of recycling farm plastics in the last six or seven years. It has been a difficult operating environment, but I am pleased to say that we have worked our way through financial and storage pressures that were there over the last few years and are in a very good space now. If members have not had an opportunity to do so already, I recommend they look at the IFAC independent review, particularly the executive summary, which highlights how difficult the recycling market was. Not only did we navigate our way through that difficult market but we continued to achieve record recycling levels. However, we are aware there are no grounds for complacency. The current geopolitical situation is very uncertain, so we have to stay alert and agile to deal with anything else that comes our way.
I thank the committee for the invitation today and we look forward to engaging with members in a constructive discussion.

The IFAC report has been circulated to members. It will not be included in the minutes of the meeting but it will be published as part of any of the correspondence that would be available to members, along with the opening statement. I have seven speakers offering. Deputy Fitzmaurice has ten minutes.

I will do quick-fire questions, to Ms Kiely first. The Department is reviewing a licence renewal at the moment. I presume she knows off the top of her head the amount of plastic that is lying in yards around the country. What tonnage is it?
It is a moving target, if you like. It is monitored by the enforcement-----
Most of the plastic is gathered now, so let us be honest. What are the figures around Ireland at the moment, in all the different yards, before the Department gives out a licence?
I will defer to the scheme on that. We are not operating-----
Sorry, you are the Department, you give out licences. Obviously the Department would have an independent assessor going around checking that up, so what is the tonnage?
We are not deciding the licence today.
What?
We are not deciding the licence today.
I know that. I asked what is the tonnage today. Obviously the Department has an up-to-date account of it.
I can give the Deputy the last figures I have. At the end of September we were advised that there was approximately 24,440 tonnes of farm plastics stored at contractors' yards.
Is that advised by somebody else or does the Department have its own independent person who looks?
In the first instance, the IFFPG gives us information and that is verified with the-----
Yes I understand that but does the Department have its own independent assessor?
The waste enforcement regional lead authority, WERLA is there, which is the local authority enforcement body. They verify on a monthly basis.
They have a person who goes out to each yard and they know the accurate tonnage. They have a QS who is able to assess it. Is that right?
They go out if they need to go out, or-----
Are those figures available to this committee where each person went out to different yards and assessed the tonnage?
We can get that kind of information for the Deputy if he likes.
Okay. At the moment I am aware there is an investigation from Europe into plastics in Ireland. Is the Department aware of that?
We are aware of that but we are not party to it.
Has the Department to do any correspondence on that?
Not now. I do not think we have either. We have not provided any input into it.
There are 24,000 tonnes around the country, going by what Ms Kiely is saying. My next question is to IFFPG. Where does most of its plastic go at the moment?
Our plastic is going to a combination of Irish and European facilities.
What are the European facilities? Is that Cedo?
Cedo is actually in the process of-----
Is Mr. Moloney aware that Cedo is now closed or closing?
It is in the process of relocating to another facility elsewhere, that is right. It is relocating at the moment.
Will that cause a problem?
We would prefer if it were open but we can manage it. We have enough recycling capacity elsewhere.
What percentage is recycled in Ireland in tonnage?
It is 50:50, so last year around 50% was-----
What is 50%? Give me tonnage.
That was 20,000 tonnes. We recycled 40,000 tonnes last year and half was recycled in Ireland.
Were 40,000 tonnes recycled altogether?
Correct.

Of that, 20,000 tonnes was recycled in Ireland. There is one plant in Ireland that had 4,000 tonnes of a licence and looked for 20,000 tonnes last January. I understand Mr. Moloney's operation has sent plastic to it since. It was refused a licence. Does that worry Mr. Moloney?
I am not aware of any such action. We are supplying plastic just to permitted facilities and the facilities we are supplying to have permits at this time and point.
For running this business, going by the figures I am looking at, what does Mr. Moloney's business get paid for by the importers every year?
We charge companies that put plastic on the market in the first instance through the recycling levy.
How many tonnes come in that you get paid for?
It varies but it is in the region of 20,000 to 22,000 tonnes.
Then when it is going out, it is obviously twice as heavy.
Correct.
So that is 40,000 tonnes. So you would get €286 for the 22,000 tonnes and €120 for the 40,000 tonnes. Is that right?
That is correct.
A tonne is costing roughly around €500, would that be right?
The Deputy can add up the figures and see what it is costing at the moment. It is costing the €286 plus the €120 per tonne to recycle what we are recycling.
You will have twice as much tonnage then, going out, will you not?
There is twice as much tonnage, exactly.
So the €120 is €240 really.
Yes.
So €240 and €286 would be €526 a tonne, which is what it is costing the farmers. It is the farmers who are paying this.
Ultimately, yes.
It was €5 a roll. That is what we used to put it down as. It is actually costing something like €11 or €12 a roll now when we double it.
Excluding VAT, around €7.40 or €7.50.
That is when it comes in but when it goes out as well.
That is the price excluding VAT for the farmer when they buy the product, the hardware.
I am talking about when they get rid of it as well. It is costing about €12 a roll when you add it up
It could well be.
Maybe more, maybe €14.
The IFFPG is forward paid by the different companies. Is it this time of year they are paid?
Typically, we are paid from May onwards.
For the amount of tonnage around the country, what financial lump has the group in the kitty? If there is 24,000 tonnes, is the IFFPG paid now for next year's import part?

No. Next year, when the product goes on the market, we will get the money for next year. We are in a very good financial position at the moment and well capable of covering the recession cost of everything that we have in storage.
What is that?
Is the Deputy asking how much is in storage at the moment?
No, I am asking about the group's financial position. What is the financial back-up?
If the Deputy was to look at our reserve, which is total assets minus liabilities, we would probably-----
I am talking about cash and cash is needed to get rid of plastic.
Yes. We would have at the moment not far off €3 million.
Going by what I am looking at, if there is 24,000 tonnes around the country and the charge is €125 a tonne, will that get rid of plastic at the moment?
It would.
Will it?
We are going to get more money coming through in the new year as well.
If €125 a tonne gets rid of plastic, which means €3 million will get rid of 24,000 tonnes. So why are farmers paying €540 a tonne?

Maybe the Deputy did not get a chance to look at our audited accounts, which are published on our website. The accounts show the amount of money that we need, that we bring in and what we spend. At the moment we are generating a surplus and we feel very comfortable that we have enough money.
Can you square that circle for me? Mr. Moloney has said that the IFFPG can get rid of the plastic at the moment at a cost of €125 a tonne.
This is what the Deputy is saying, yes.
No, Mr. Moloney is saying that.
No.

Mr. Moloney has said that his group has €3 million in its account. At the moment it has been stated that there are 24,440 tonnes of plastic around Ireland. If every bit of that plastic is got rid of, Mr. Moloney has said that his group is financially solvent, and if I calculate the figure rough in my head then it costs €125 a tonne to get rid of every bit of the plastic if the group has €3 million in its account. That is what Mr. Moloney is saying his group can rid of the plastic for but I am saying that farmers, between what they are paying coming in and going out, is paying €540. Where is the discrepancy? Either the group has not a heap of money in the bank or there is a link missing.
There is no discrepancy and there is no link missing. If the Deputy looks at our accounts for last year he will see that we-----
I am not questioning the accounts but the figures in terms of what Mr. Moloney has said.

I can only speak in aggregate terms. At the end of this year, we will have collected and recycled in the region of 40,000 tonnes and we will expect to still have €2.5 million to €3 million in the bank, and more money will be coming in in the new year. By the end of this year we would expect to have no more than, maybe, 14,000 or 15,000 tonnes in the yards.
If there is a problem with Cedo in Holland, which is my understanding from everything that I have read, it means 20,000 tonnes is in a bit of jeopardy at the moment., is it?

We were not quite sending them that much but we are working hard at the moment and putting in place notifications to supply to other recyclers in Europe. We expect some of those notifications to come through quite shortly. Indeed, when Cedo relocates to another location we will also supply to it at that new location.
Is it fair to say the IFFPG sends plastic to different plants in Ireland?
Yes.
How many?
At the moment, three.
They are recycling plants.
Yes.
If there was a problem, does the Department watch where the plastic goes? If there was a problem with planning, would the Department be concerned?
If we are notified by the enforcement authority of the local authority or the EPA, of course that would be a matter of concern.
If notified.
Yes.
On contracts, is the Department open to different operators submitting a proposal in smaller scale around the country? What is the story with that?
If the producers of the plastics, who put the products on the market, come forward with their proposal we will look at it of course.

Hold on now. Ms Kiely said, "the producers of the plastics". With all due respect, they do not produce plastic. They gather it. The producers are the crowds that make it or import it. Is that who Ms Kiely is saying has to make an application?
The people who place the plastic on the market in Ireland, whether they produce it or retail it here as the first people to place it on the market.
Is that closed to just them? With due respect, the IFFPG does not place plastic on the market in Ireland. Are there different rules for different folks?
No. The members of the IFFPG, please correct me if I am wrong, are producers of plastic.
So what the IFFPG is saying is that the importers are members of IFFPG. That is grand.
The next speaker listed is Senator Boyhan but Deputy Cleere is here.

The IFFPG has operated as the approved body since 1998 and its approval is reviewed on an ongoing five-yearly basis. I also know that it is open to producers to establish an alternative scheme at any time. Is this advertised for alternative producers?
It is not advertised at any particular point in time. No more than for any material stream, we do not advertise.

Does that not sound funny? There is a contract awarded for five years. With any local authority contract, where there is a deal with somebody for five years there is a public consultation to see if anybody else wants to come in and bid and, maybe, do a better deal. Ms Kiely has said that the Department does not even advertise this. It is just tick a box every five years and away you go.

It is not a contract. When the regulations were made, back in the day, the obligation was placed on producers to put a scheme together. It was from that day forward that producers could approach the Department on any day of the week with a proposal. It just so happens that the proposal that came in is on its fifth-year anniversary.
Earlier Ms Kiely said that the Department is not aware of interest by other groups in applying for ministerial approval, but it is not advertised anywhere.
No, but producers are aware that they have an obligation to do that.
To be clinical, it is not advertised.
No.

That seems strange to me. On the financial elements of the operation, I note that there has been significant increases in both the levy and collection charges in recent years. Please indicate where they have come from and where they are now. So we know now it is €286 per tonne and €120 per tonne at the collection points. What was it five years ago?
That question is for the group.

In simple terms, the levy and collection charges have pretty much doubled in the last four or five years. That has been necessary to meet the huge increase in recycling costs associated with all the global events of which we are aware.
Are there financial incentives for farmers?

On the financial incentive in terms of the collection charge, because we charge by weight the farmer has an incentive to take out any pieces of contamination and we have made a lot of progress in that particular area. There is an incentive on that front.
Is there a cash or financial incentive?
No. Unfortunately, the plastic has a huge negative value and the scheme is very expensive to run. So we have to charge both the members and farmers at the current rates in order to wash our face.
Can introducing incentives for farmers be considered in the future?

In the past, when our finances were very flush, which was ten or 12 years ago, we reduced both the recycling levy and collection charges to farmers. If we should get into such a position again we would most certainly consider reducing both the levy and collection charges. We are a not-for-profit body but we must have a certain amount of funding in order to run ourselves.

I want to discuss the lack of infrastructure. I am a rural Deputy from Carlow-Kilkenny and sometimes there is a lack of infrastructure in areas. There are four providers. How many collection points are located around the country?

Typically, we run about 200 bring-centres so, on average, there are seven or eight bring-centres per county. Farmers can also drop the material into our contractors' yards and there is a farmyard collection service for farmers who prefer that service.
Deputy Fitzmaurice mentioned that there is about 24,000 tonnes in storage at the moment.
Looking at the existing operators, their maximum capacity is less than 24,000 tonnes.
No, that would not be correct. Our contractors have a storage capacity of 45,000 tonnes. In recent years, a number of them have come through the planning process and the permit review process.
That contradictory to the IFAC report.
No, it is not. The IFAC report talks about it going up to 45,000 tonnes this year.
Page 36 of the IFAC report gives a breakdown per entity. The figures are 3,500 tonnes, ten tonnes, 2,100 tonnes and 10,000 tonnes.
Yes, but also if you-----
Is this out of date?
If you look at the detail of the IFAC report, you will also see that it expects capacity to go up to 45,000 tonnes by the end of this year. The capacity has actually already gone up to 45,000 tonnes.
That is not in this report, just to be very clear. It must be an older report. I just wanted to acknowledge that. Is there much plastic coming in from the North?

There is a problem with the illegal trade. Plastic is definitely coming down from the North. We have no statutory enforcement powers. We work with the local authorities and the WERLAs and do all we can to assist them but there is an issue with illegal plastic coming from the North.
Roughly how much, in tonnage terms?

It is impossible to quantify an illegal activity because there are no records. It could be 5% or 10%. It could be higher in the Border counties. There is a problem with illegal plastics. There always has been. All we can do is work to minimise it.
Let us say it is roughly 10%. If we bring in about 40 million tonnes, we would be looking at about 4 million tonnes, give or take, based on those mathematics.
Typically, there is 20,000 to 22,000 tonnes going on the market so 1,500 to 2,000 tonnes might be being lost, but it is impossible to say.
Okay, it is about 2,000 tonnes. On recycling in Ireland, 20,000 tonnes are done in Ireland and 20,000 abroad. What is the breakdown of that international side?
It typically goes to the UK or Holland. We are working to put notifications in place to supply to other countries such as Poland and Lithuania.
Why are we not doing it in Ireland?

At the moment, the maximum recycling capacity is 20,000 tonnes and we are meeting that demand from Irish recyclers. We are working with the Irish recyclers and encouraging them to expand. We would love for everything to be recycled in Ireland.
What kind of economic benefits do farm films bring to local rural economies? What kind of employment are we looking at?

We have five contractors who typically employ between five and ten people. There is some employment there. There are also three recyclers, who employ ten, 15 or 20 people each, so there is employment there as well. Our key role is to provide a service to farmers and to hit recycling targets, and we do that very well.
What kind of turnover was achieved last year in terms of farm payments and the tonnage that came through?
As a company, our turnover was approximately €10.5 million for the year.
Will Mr. Moloney say a little bit about regulatory challenges?

As the Deputy mentioned, there is an issue with illegal product coming down from the North. We work very hard with the county councils, which have the remit for enforcing farm plastics regulations, and with the WERLAs. We do all we can to identify potential illegal operators, bring them to the attention of authorities, and help in whatever way we can to close those operators and, ideally, to get a prosecution.
Is there a possibility of a compatible scheme being established in the North? There may be some cross-Border challenges. Has the IFFPG explored that area? Where is it in that regard?

One of the recommendations of the IFAC review was that we would explore that. We are in the early stages of exploring that with the Department. We are going to see what is possible there. It certainly would be a big help if there were a comparable scheme in Northern Ireland because it would reduce the price difference between the North and the Republic.
Is the Department satisfied that the IFFPG is engaging positively with the regulations?
Yes.
On the public awareness campaigns, I believe Mr. Moloney said there were 100,000 farmers engaged in this scheme. How many are not? Is it 20,000?

CSO figures suggest there might be 135,000 livestock farmers, but it must be borne in mind that some livestock farmers do not winter cattle and others winter only very small numbers of cattle and might get rid of their plastic in their wheelie bin. The overwhelming majority of farmers who are farming in any sort of serious way are engaging with the scheme.
What percentage of farmers are not engaging in the scheme?
The IFAC report identified that 77% of farmers are engaging with the scheme.
That means 23% are not. I am worried about this 23%. What are we doing to engage with this 23%? What educational programmes are in place? How are we getting at that 23%?

We are advertising as hard as we can through various media. We advertise in the Irish Farmers' Journal and on Agriland. We text message farmers and advertise through the IFA and Farm TV. We are interested in getting as many farmers as possible engaging with the scheme. The numbers are currently huge so there is already massive engagement, but we would like to see as many more as possible avail of our services.
That is fine. I thank Mr. Moloney very much.

I will have to tip off in a minute because I am going to speak on farm safety. Regarding the IFFPG, there is a levy on the purchase of farm plastic. Per roll, that is roughly €5 to €7. It is actually more now. With the new contractors and the new balers, there is no netting going on. A double layer of plastic goes on bales, which results in almost a third more plastic coming into the sector. Does Mr. Moloney accept that?

Netting is reducing. As the Senator is probably aware, we do collect netting as well. It is being replaced with net replacement film. There is still quite a volume of netting going on the market. The net replacement film is collected and recycled with the wrap and the sheeting. We collect the net replacement film as well.
It is collected with the plastic.
Exactly. It is collected with the wrap and the sheeting.
The IFFPG will therefore have seen an increase in tonnage in the last 12 months.

It is not so much determined by that. The increase is largely determined by the weather. If we have a very long winter, we will collect more plastic. If we have a very short winter, we will collect less plastic. The market itself is determined by the weather. If we have really good growth conditions, we see a big increase in plastic because more silage is made. If the weather is difficult, we see less silage made. The weather is the big determining factor. For the most part, the net replacement film is replacing netting, which is reducing.
Roughly the same amount of silage is made year on year.
It is approximately the same, yes.
What I am saying is that netting will reduce and plastic will increase.
Yes.
Mr. Moloney is telling me that the IFFPG is doing roughly 40,000 tonnes of recycling a year.
Yes.
That is going to increase in the next year or two by whatever percentage because there will be less netting and more plastic.
Yes.
That will come at a higher cost.
Yes, but it must be remembered that we will be collecting less netting. That will be compensated by the increase in net replacement film. One will largely cancel out the other.
The fee for the netting at the beginning is, let us say, €7 a roll. When the farmer brings it in for recycling, it is roughly €14 per tonne when it is weighed in. Does Mr. Moloney accept that?
The cost per tonne is €120. The minimum charge is €60 for a half tonne at the moment. They are the costs.
It is twice the weight.
It is twice the weight, yes.
What I am saying is that figure of 40,000 tonnes will be greater going forward.
It might be slightly more. For example-----
If I may make this point, we had a short winter, so collections are down 15% this year.
The plastic is still there.
It is and it is not.
It might not have been collected but it is still there on the farms.

Most farmers bring it out on a one-year cycle. Some do so on a two- or three-year cycle. On the Senator's point on net replacement film, all things being equal, it will slightly increase the amount we collect. The net replacement plastic is heavier than the netting but, as we collect more net replacement plastic, we collect less netting.
The cost is going to go up, therefore.
I do not see that as necessarily being the case.
The figures say that the IFFPG had roughly €3 million of a surplus.
We expect something like that at the year's end, yes.
That is 40,000 tonnes recycled.
It is 40,000 tonnes this year, yes.
If we break that down, it will be less than €125 a tonne.

It would make more sense to look at our accounts for last year. That would give the Senator the big picture and let him know how much we get in from the levy and from collection income and how much recycling we are collecting.
How much does the IFFPG get from the levy?
It is typically around €6 million a year.
How much does the IFA get from the levy?

The IFA does not get any money from the levy. Separately, the farmers pay a weight-based collection charge, which might make up another €4 million or €4.5 million. That is overall funding for the scheme.
If you want to look at a breakdown of our costs, between €9 million and €9.5 million is spent on collecting and recycling it, and a bit on administration.
There are five approved contractors at the moment.
That is right.
Is that adequate for the whole country?

I think it is adequate. To be honest, we would like to have more collectors, but it is hard to get people to engage with our tendering process because the business is niche and seasonal. We advertised our most recent national tendering process extensively but not a huge number of tenders were submitted. However, we can provide a good service, as we are currently doing with five collectors.
I am sure the five approved contractors would need to have EPA licences.
They would either have to have an EPA licence or a county council permit, and they are all properly permitted.
I return to the 24,000 tonnes that are already here. That is in yards.
Yes.
What will the cost be to recycle that at the moment?

The best way I can answer that without running figures in my head is to say that to recycle 40,000 tonnes this year, which is what we expect to recycle, will cost approximately €4.5 million. That is the easiest way I can answer that. To collect between 38,000 tonnes and 40,000 tonnes or whatever we intend to collect will probably cost another €4.5 million.
To collect 40,000 tonnes will cost how much?
It will probably cost another €4.5 million. Our operating costs will probably be between €9 million and €10 million depending on where the figures fall by the end of the year.
Some 24,000 tonnes at €125 per tonne comes in at €3 million.
I have not run the figure, but if that is what it comes to, yes.
If 24,000 tonnes at €125 per tonne costs €3 million, how is Mr. Moloney going to do 40,000 tonnes for €4 million?
Overall, all I can tell the Senator is that we will spend approximately €4 million this year.
It is not adding up.
It is adding up. The €125 per tonne was the Senator's figure, not our figure.
What is their figure?
Our figure would divide 40,000-----
No, what is their figure? Have they a price on it?
The only way I could give that figure is to divide €4.5 million by 40,000 and you will see the cost of recycling.
That is the net.

If the Senator is trying to find out if the scheme is financially stable, which is what I think he is coming at, this scheme is financially stable at the moment. We have enough money to do what we need to do and to put enough aside to satisfy the requirements of our approver. The Senator can rest assured that the scheme is financially stable. I cannot be running figures here in my head, but I can point him to our audited accounts from last year, which will give him all the detail with regard to what the company takes in from certain areas and spends in certain areas.

It is hard to accept that. Coming into a committee we should have figures in our heads. I go back to collaboration and the illegal tonnage coming across. Mr. Moloney stated approximately one third of it, is that correct?
No, we estimate between 5% and 10%, but we do not know for sure it is illegal activity. Between 5% and 10% of the market is perhaps lost to this illegal activity, but we do not know for sure.
How is that funded?
It is lost, it is illegally put on the market, and we have to fund our scheme with what is legally put on the market.
Is that in the 40,000 tonnes?
We do all we can when the material comes in at bring centres to check to see if the levy has been paid so we are working hard there and with the local authorities and the-----
Is it in the 40,000 tonnes they have estimated?

There may be some illegal product in there. I could not say for sure, but we are doing all we can to make sure there are checks in place at the bring centre when the farmer comes in to make sure he has paid the levy.
IFAC estimates up to 25%.

That was a possible figure, but we would say between 5% and 10%. They quoted various people they interviewed. Some said 25% and some said different figures. Our feeling is that it is between 5% and 10% of the market.
Is the 5% or 10% included in the 40,000 tonnes in this year's estimate?
Some illegal product and plastic might make its way into our bring centres despite our best efforts. I cannot say for sure.
Mr. Moloney gave me a figure there.
Yes.
It is either in the figure or it is not. Is it in it?
If a farmer buys illegal product and is in some way able to trick us into thinking that he paid the levy, that plastic may end up at our bring centre.
The figure Mr. Moloney is giving the committee today is that they are going to recycle 40,000 tonnes.
Yes.
Is that 40,000 tonnes in the Republic of Ireland or is that including the 5% Mr. Moloney is saying is already recyclable? That is all I am asking.

The only way I can answer that question is by saying we are doing all we can to check to ensure that everything that comes into our bring centres has the levy paid on it. If it does not, we have a traceability system whereby a farmer has to present a code. He gets the code when he buys the plastic. The code is validated, and he has produced proof of purchase. If the farmer is able to trick us - if he has bought illegal plastic - into thinking he has paid the levy when he has not, then we will take the plastic.
Surely Mr. Moloney and his company knows all the plastic that is imported per tonne. Double that up in the Republic of Ireland and it gives you a figure.
Yes.
Are those figures adding up with what they have?
They are adding up.
Then they are not losing anything from illegal activity.
Okay.
If the figures add up, they are not losing anything.

There is collecting the plastic and what goes on the market. Of what goes on the market we reckon between 5% and 10% is being lost to the illegal trade. We are doing all we can through our traceability system at bring centres to ensure farmers who might have bought illegal plastic cannot get the plastic weighed at our bring centres at the lower price. That is what we are doing there.

I thank the witnesses for their opening statements. I suppose a lot of this has been teased through. There are basically five contractors doing the work. If you have a situation where those contractors are not able to get rid of the product they have and it builds up, what happens then? Where do they reach capacity and what mechanism can kick in?

Although we have five collectors collecting the plastic, we retain ownership of the plastic. It is our responsibility in its entirety. We must ensure that those yards are kept under their limit. We work hard with the contractors and our recyclers to make that happen. Once a contractor collects plastic on our behalf, we have a responsibility to make sure that plastic goes for recycling, and that is what we do.
Have they had instances where that has not happened?

We have had situations over the past few years. I alluded to this in my opening statement, where yards were under storage pressure because we were collecting so much plastic and at the time there was not enough storage capacity. That issue has been addressed now by getting more recycling capacity and by a number of contractors expanding their yards. They have gone through the planning and permit review processes. We have almost doubled our storage capacity in the past year or year and a half.
Those permits are generally issued by local authorities in most cases.
Exactly.
Is it a slow process to get additional contractors and yards if needed?

The process involves having a national contractor tendering process every five years. We advertise it heavily and we look for as many applicants as possible to get tenders in. We assess those tenders, and we go with the best tenders on offer. That is the process.

In respect of exports, it has been alluded to that there is a difficulty in one of the main facilities in Europe at the moment and where the additional level of plastic will go. The amount of plastic that has to be exported is substantial because we do not have the capacity here to deal with it. Are we in a situation where Mr. Moloney could foresee a difficulty in the future if that facility in the Netherlands were not to reopen or come back on stream?

We hope not because we are working hard with the authorities in various countries in Europe to get permission to supply facilities located elsewhere. We are also hopeful that Cedo will relocate its plant to another country, and we would be looking to supply there. We feel quite comfortable that we have enough recycling capacity.

A lot of this comes down to the money collected from the farmer, because the farmer ultimately pays for all of this. There is the money collected from the farmer and the money in this system. I respect Mr. Moloney's attempt to be clear about this but there are lots of hazy areas. Certainly, many farmers feel that they are not sure what is happening, where it is all going and how it is all working out. The maximum amount of clarity and transparency around that needs to be brought to the table. It is something that has raised a lot of questions in the past. There is maybe an opportunity to relieve that and put additional and better processes in place.
I take the Deputy's point. Perhaps we have a job of work to communicate more effectively with farmers exactly how we are funded and how we spend our money.

On the amount of illegal plastic, I live in the Border county of Leitrim and I am aware it is something that happens. There may be many farmers who may not purchase all their film north of the Border, but would get a proportion of it there. How hard is it to trace that? The farmer might have a receipt and a code for plastic. Sometimes there is a guy who arrives in a truck to pick it or sometimes there is a collection area in the yard at a mart and the plastic is just thrown. They are not going to be weighing it or checking it in very much detail.

We have a traceability system. I am not saying it is watertight but we have made big efforts just this year to tighten it up. We have had a very heavy advertising campaign aimed at farmers. We have said to them they will be charged double if they cannot confirm when they come into a bring centre that they have brought levied plastic. They have to bring in a valid label code and proof of purchase. It is checked on an app. We feel we are doing all we can. That is not to say there is not some leakage. I am not going to say the system is watertight but we are making it as uncomfortable and difficult as possible for farmers to buy unlevied plastic, bring it into the bring centre and avail of the lower charges.

Obviously the Department has a role here in the oversight. I am sure the officials are aware that a lot of people in the farming community have a lot of questions and have raised eyebrows about the finances of this operation. What level of oversight do the officials have at present? At what level do they feel they need to have an additional role in respect of that?

We meet the group regularly. We have an approval document as well as the regulation, so there is a template for us to ensure there is compliance with all the terms of the approval and the regulations. The scheme is obliged to publish an annual report in the first half of the year and that is available on its website every year. That gives very comprehensive detail on the tonnages that have been collected and recycled and the money that has gone through the scheme. There is a wealth of information there on the scheme, so it is very transparent. We are conscious that as conditions in the market vary, different challenges arise for the group over time. By keeping good communication between the Department and the group we are satisfied we get good notice of any issues that arise and what the scheme is doing to meet those challenges.
Is there an issue that it is basically a closed shop?

No. Our objectives are that the plastic is taken out of the environment and safely recycled and that farmers have a cost-effective and efficient system to that end. The obligation is on the producers. If you want to sell plastic into the Irish market, you have to participate in this scheme or set up a deposit and return scheme under the regulations. All producers have come in behind this scheme and they are complying with their obligations under the regulations by doing so.

Going back to the bigger picture, we expect additional levels of recyclables being required to be taken care of. Are there plans to expand the capacity in the country to do that so we have less of a dependence on export?
Yes. Mr. Moloney has outlined his efforts to maximise the material that is recycled within the country and if there were more operators available to do that he would send material to them.

Absolutely. We would like to recycle everything in Ireland if we could but there is just insufficient capacity at the moment. We are working with the recyclers to encourage them to expand so we can get more of it recycled in Ireland. The end goal would be to recycle everything here, if at all possible.
Are there technological advances that are improving the prospect of that?

It is a difficult business. It is very capital-intensive. It is difficult to recycle the plastic and the markets are not brilliant at the moment for the finished product. Nonetheless, we have three Irish recyclers operating and they are taking 50% of what we recycle, which is a big improvement on three or four years ago. We will keep working with them and encouraging them and I hope we will see that capacity increase in Ireland.

My first question is for the producers group. In my area outside Portlaoise we had a collection yard licensed by the local authority in Clonkeen. You bought your permit or you brought your licence, you weighed in, you paid your money and you went off, and that plastic is still out there now. What has the group planned to remove that plastic? I am a public representative who represents that area as well. That is the first question.

Any plastic we have responsibility for in that yard has been removed. The plastic that is in that yard now is not the IFFPG's responsibility. It has come from other sources. That is not our responsibility. We have taken everything we owned out of that yard, so I am afraid we can give no further assistance with regard to that yard.
Mr. Moloney is telling me the plastic I brought into that yard is gone.
I am telling the Deputy that the plastic we supplied into the facility-----
I am sorry, but how does Mr. Moloney know that? There was a big pile of plastic. Did the group go through it or what?
Because we-----
I am asking you straight up.

Indeed. We did an audit. We did an audit of that particular contractor's yard and we did a match between what went in and what was recycled in that particular contractor's recycling facility because that contractor also had a recycling facility. We were able to see that we had recycling certificates received from the recycler for everything we put into the yard, so we have taken full responsibility for everything we have-----
You are saying that you got no levy on the plastic that is left in the yard.
I am not saying that. I am saying it is not our plastic.

If you are not saying that, you will have to come out and prove that you did not take the levy. If you claimed the levy off the plastic that went in there and is in there, in my opinion you have a responsibility to move that.
No. That plastic has come from other sources. We have-----
What do you mean by other sources? Where can it come from?

Other collectors that were operating outside the IFFPG scheme. The IFFPG has carried out a detailed audit of that yard. We are 100% certain that we have recycling certificates back from the recycler for everything we put into the yard. The plastic that is in that yard has come from non-IFFPG sources. We sympathise with the position the yard finds itself in but we have no responsibility there.

What will happen then eventually? I think you have an awful lot more. I cannot understand what you are telling me, because no matter where the plastic came out of - and 5% comes from outside the country or from the North of Ireland and you say you cannot account for that, which is fair enough - the group got money out of the other amount of plastic that is there. That is Irish plastic.
There may or may not have been a levy-----
Mine is in there.

-----paid on it, but it was other collectors who collected it and it was a recycler who took it in but it has not been recycled. It is not our responsibility. We are 100% sure that everything we put into that yard-----

But you got the money for the plastic. I am not happy because you get money for every piece of plastic that is wrapped around a bale or put on a silage pit, like I do. You got the levy. I brought it out there and I handed in my notes saying where I got it, 100% above board. The people in the area are asking me. That plastic is there. You got money out of that and now you are walking away from your responsibility, in my opinion.
The money we get from our members is there to run our scheme. We collect plastic through our approved collectors.
Yes, and I am one of them.

Yes. Therefore, if the Deputy dropped plastic into that yard with our approved collector at the time, his plastic was recycled because we are certain that everything we dropped into that yard was recycled by the recycler. We have paperwork and an audit to confirm that.
So is the question about who brought it in, not where it came from?
We will take responsibility for what we have responsibility for. That yard was also-----
But you have the money.
You have the money.
-----being supplied by plastic from non-IFFPG sources. We are not taking responsibility for the plastic that came from non-IFFPG sources.
Would you accept that your group drew the money from the people who imported it-----
Deputy.
-----into this country? You drew the money and the Department should wake up to the fact that money is drawn from-----
Deputy.
-----all importers into this country and then if someone else has it, tough luck, leave it there. That is some set-up. The Department should wake up to what is going on.
Deputy Aird, it is your time.

The bottom line is that the plastic is there. I am asking the Department as well. I want this plastic moved. It is in an area and the people are entitled to have it removed because there was a subsidy paid on that. Someone somewhere has the money for it. In fairness, this non-profit organisation still has €3 million in the bank. All I am saying is that this has to be moved. I do not know how anybody would be able to say exactly that my plastic is gone.
Do you understand? I am just saying that. I do not know how that is done. We will be in again and we will come back to that. I just think it is wrong, if you understand what I mean.

I have a couple of questions I would like to ask. As we all know, with levy and collection charges rising sharply, what steps are being taken to stabilise or reduce the costs to farmers while maintaining high recycling rates? It is a quickfire question because I have only four and a half minutes left.

The money we are charging in the levy and collection charges is the money that we have to charge at the moment to fund the scheme. That is the cost of collecting and recycling 40,000 tonnes of plastic every year. It is regrettable but that is where it is. If we do not charge at that level, we will erode our financial resources.

There are only five approved collectors now for the whole country. As Mr. Moloney said, this is seasonal work. How will this scheme ensure that farmers in the most remote areas will get a fair collection with only five people?

Those five people are able to provide that comprehensive collection. We ran 200 bring centres this year with our five collectors. We do it every year. We provide a farmyard collection service for farmers who cannot make the bring centre. We are able to provide a comprehensive and timely collection service for farmers with five collectors.

How does the Department ensure that the producer pays model works fairly without shifting the excess cost to farmers? I feel that the farmer is paying an excessive amount at the moment for this scheme. That is my personal opinion as a farmer.

The obligation is on the scheme to balance the books. As Mr. Moloney outlined, the cost of recycling is such that the fees required are the fees required to make sure that the collection and recycling costs could be met. There was a time when you could be paid for your plastic. Obviously, those times have passed and now it is a cost. There is a widespread difficulty in the recycling industry across Europe, as the market for recycled plastics has suffered a number of shocks from pressures elsewhere in the world. It is a difficult business to be in and unfortunately that translates into high costs for the people who use the plastic. We acknowledge that the consumers and customers of those producers are ultimately the ones who-----
What actions did the Department require of the IFFPG after the mid-2024 review, monitoring compliance and so on? What did the Department ask of it?

It was set out in a letter to the committee too. It touched on things like training of the board to ensure the highest standards of governance at board level, working with enforcement authorities to ensure that non-compliant retailers were targeted, developing an enforcement portal, and working on the product codes so that farmers who have paid for the levy at the time of purchase have proof when they are they are bringing it to the collection and to ensure that non-levied plastic does not get into the collection system. It also addressed the storage of legacy farm plastic which had built up in the yards over the years but has now been tackled successfully. They were the main issues.
The IFFPG is the only approved scheme as we speak here today. What is being done to encourage alternative or competing recycling schemes? If we do not do that, we are going nowhere.

There is an annual promotion by the scheme of what the scheme does. That creates an awareness of the obligation to have a scheme, that there is activity and that a service is being provided. There is a high level of awareness of the requirement for a scheme. All that awareness has not generated an application from anybody else to run an alternative scheme.
We have been told that 50% of what IFFPG collects is being recycled in three different centres. Is that correct?
Some 50% in Ireland and the other 50% abroad.
That is 50% in Ireland. Has IFFPG to pay those recycling centres?
Yes.
How much is IFFPG paying them?
The best way to answer that is that last year, we spent €4.5 million supplying plastic to centres.

It is very difficult. When Mr. Moloney says IFFPG spent €4.5 million paying these people, I am trying to see how much less money it should be taking out of farmers' pockets in the levy for plastics because, as far as I can see, the only person who is paying money is the farmer. He is carrying the whole book. Farm incomes are reducing at the moment. Milk is going down and cereals have nearly gone out of business. From a recycling point of view, IFFPG takes plastic drums in. I am asking the Department to look into recycling them. Look at what happened with the plastic bottles. You could not get a plastic bottle anywhere in this country if you were searching. I know that because we used to be collecting because our farm was near the town. There is not a plastic bottle to be seen since there have been refunds for them. Can the Department not think outside the box on something like that? Wash out the 5 gallon drums that are coming in with all the different stuff, then they can be recycled and stuff can be put back into them. It is nonsensical and the Department should be doing something like that. If the Department continues the way it is going, there is no incentive for any recycling. Some 50% is being recycled and the Department is going to store the other 50% if it can and send it out of the country. Be honest about it.

We should be able to do our own recycling of plastic in the country. I am fearful that there is no push to increase that 50%. The Department should learn from the plastic bottles. Everyone would agree that it was the best scheme that ever came out, which everybody in every town and village in the country is using. The Department should be thinking outside the box. The witnesses' organisations should be happy enough, since they have €3 million already, and I am giving them part of that €3 million as a farmer, as is every other farmer. They have all the money. That could go up to €4 million or €5 million. It is time that we gave a reduction back to the farmer.

I welcome the witnesses. The economics of this just do not make sense. I have listened for the past hour. In the levy, €6 million paid by the farmer is taken in. The collection fee is over €4 million, also paid by the farmer. That is a total revenue turnover of €10 million. The cost per tonne of removing recycling is €112, by the witnesses' figures, as they said to Deputy 'Chap' Cleere. There are 40,000 tonnes per year and it costs about €4.5 million to dispose of it at €112 per tonne. There should be a yearly surplus, on those figures, of about €5.5 million. Where is the money going?

It would be, except we also collect the plastic and bale it before we send it to the recycler. Another €4.5 million is spent on collecting, baling and preparing the plastic for recycling, then €4.5 million is spent on sending it to the recyclers. I assure the Deputy that we are not awash with money. If anything, financially, it has been quite challenging for the last few years but our finances are stable and good now. We are generating a modest surplus and building up our contingency. We have pretty much just enough money to provide the service we are currently providing.
How many people work in the organisation?
There are only five people in the office. Our administrative costs are around €600,000 a year.
What are the top three salaries of individuals in the organisation?

I am not revealing that but I can tell the Deputy that €600,000 per year is spent on administration. That includes salaries, rent of the office, advertising and consultancy. I assure the Deputy that there is no waste when it comes to the administration of the scheme.
Mr. Moloney mentioned a recycling cost of €112 per tonne but exporters are saying it is €150 per tonne. Who is wrong and who is right?

We can talk about that until the cows come home. I can tell the Deputy what we are spending overall on recycling 40,000 tonnes. It will come in at around €4.5 million. We will spend another €4.5 million on collecting that 40,000 tonnes and baling it. We have administration costs of around €600,000 and we will take in maybe €10 million to €10.5 million depending on how the year pans out. This scheme just about washes its face. It generates a little surplus, which we need, because we need to build up our contingency fund, so there is no surplus of money but we are financially stable.
Where is the company Cedo going?

I do not know and I do not know if it knows at this point but it has closed its plant in the Netherlands and is seeking to relocate the various recycling lines it had in that plant to other countries. I do not know at this time where it will relocate the farm plastic recycling to.
If it goes outside Europe, will we be able to continue to use it?
It does not intend to go outside Europe but we do not supply to any recyclers outside Europe. We will just supply to recyclers within Europe.
Four or five years ago, IFFPG was before the committee and said the recycling cost per tonne was €150 to €180. Since that time, the levy has doubled and the collection fee has doubled.

It does not really add up. What is happening? Where is the money going? How can we have a situation where the cost of recycling per tonne has fallen, yet the cost to the farmer with the levy and collection has doubled?

If the Deputy went back to our accounts of four or five years ago, he would see that we probably turning over €4 million or €5 million per year. The turnover cost of the company has doubled. Hence, unfortunately, we have had to pretty much double what we charge in the recycling levy and collection charges. We have no other form of income. We cannot get income from anywhere else. These were hard decisions. We did not like doing it. If we did not increase the levy and collection charges by the amount we increased them, the scheme would have folded. We would not have had enough money. We take in enough money to run the scheme, generate a surplus and that surplus goes into a contingency fund. The scheme is financially stable but there is no excess.
What is in the contingency fund?
That fund is building up at the moment. By the end of the year, we would expect to have around €700,000 in it.
What is the current situation in Littleton in Tipperary?
We supply plastic there on an on-off basis. We pay a gate fee, and it looks after it from there.
Is it operational as normal?
I believe so. We have nothing to do with the company apart from supplying it with plastic. It is a separate company.

I have questions for the Department. Is the Department satisfied with the economics of the scheme at the moment? Will it consider opening this up to have a greater level of competition in the market? Competition is a good thing. It appears that there is no willingness to open this up to other operators.

We have performed a lot of scrutiny of the scheme over the past number of years. There has been the independent report as well. We have done our own analysis. We have worked closely with the scheme in pointing out where we saw there was room for improvement. We have been satisfied that they have responded adequately to all of our requests. They have been quite open and transparent in that regard. We are open to an approach for any other competing body that might represent producers to set up an alternative scheme. That is absolutely the case.

It is one thing being open to it and another thing creating a process to facilitate it. There needs to be work there in relation that. There is a contract but there is no public consultation, advertising and tendering process. It seems that there is not really engagement or willingness there. Does Ms Kiely agree?

In other schemes, for example, in textiles, it is a new requirement from the EU to require the setting up of a new extended producer responsibility for textiles. We have had a number of bodies approaching us saying that would be willing to run a scheme. There is appetite out there where there is a prospect of being able to do business successfully. I would not think it was so much that it is not known to producers because all of the producers are members of the IFFPG. There are no other producers operating.
Why is it the case that the Department has precluded that outside agencies or companies, in that they must be producers?

It is a producer responsibility scheme. If you want to place material on the market, you have to take responsibility for its end-of-life destination and how it is handled. It is an obligation on the producer. If someone wants to do business here, they have to facilitate the scheme which collects and recycles the material.

That creates a closed loop. It leaves itself open to a level of or potential for corruption in relation to it if the Department is excluding any outside agency. It is a closed loop and therefore it is not open to the full competition of the market.

I do not see how it is closed. The producers can break away or new producers can come in and set up their own scheme subject to them meeting the requirements of the regulations. There is nothing to stop them doing that.
In relation to the non-levy plastic that is coming in from the North, what level of tonnage was that last year? What is the charge for that?

As I was saying earlier, we do not know for sure the illegal activity but we estimate that 5% or 10% of the market might be illegal. We do all we can at the bring centres to try to identify that plastic through our traceability system. If a farmer brings that in and he does not have a valid label code or proof of purchase, he is going to be double charged. We had a big push on that this year. We found it effective. We estimate it is maybe 5% or 10% of the market.
What tonnage of plastic was double charged last year?

summary.i: Deputy William Aird took the Chair.

speech.p: This year is the first year we went hard at that. I can talk more on farmer numbers. Two hundred to 300 farmers were perhaps double charged this year. This was a difficult thing to do because, as the Deputy, can imagine nobody wants to be double charged but we take our responsibility seriously when comes to assisting the enforcement authorities. We tightened up on the traceability this year. Some farmers ended up paying double charges.

If they had proof it was bought through the scheme that was refunded. It was just to try to address the illegal volumes of plastic coming in. If there was an issue with not having the right documentation and it was provided, that was immediately refunded. That was part of it. It was just to try to address the volumes of illegal plastic going through the scheme.

I thank the witnesses very much for coming in. Unfortunately, I had to step out to another meeting. We believe there is over 24,000 tonnes of plastic still to be collected throughout the country. Is that what we said at the outset?

To clarify that, we probably have a little less than 24,000 tonnes in yards. That is plastic has been collected. It is in our contractors' yards. We are recycling it as we go. Our bring centres are over now. By the time the bring centres start next April or May again, that should be down to no more than 7,000 or 8,000 tonnes. We want to keep a certain amount in the yards to honour our recycling agreements. That plastic is not a problem; we know it is there. We are prepared and have made arrangements for it to be recycled over the coming months.
Is that not an issue?
It is not an issue.
Is it in contractors' yards, with contractors who collected that plastic?
Yes, for us.
Was it on the organisation's behalf?
Correct.
That is fine.
Farmers have been charged twice. They are being charged the levy and then for the collection. Will Mr. Moloney explain that?

We have gone with a hybrid funding system whereby most of the funding comes through the recycling levy that is paid when the product is purchased but we also get funding through a weight base collection charge at the bring centre. We have gone with that funding model because it encourages the farmer to take contamination out of the plastic. It leads to better quality plastic being delivered and makes it easier for us to then find a recycling outset for that plastic.
The charges for collection are increasing. Are they going to continue to increase? It is putting another burden on top of the farmers.
No. For next year, we are comfortable and confident at this stage that the prices will stay the same. We expect no increases for next year.
Could we be looking at a decrease in the cost of it at the moment? Is the levy still going to be in place?

We are just not ready for a decrease yet but if our finances get into a position where we feel comfortable to give a decrease, we will do so. We have done this in the past. We have quite significantly decreased the recycling levy and collection charges going back ten or 12 years ago. Our finances will have to get into a good position before we would take that decision but we are not a for profit body. We do not hoard money. If we get to that position, we are happy to make reductions.
Is the levy going to stay as it is? The status quo will remain going forward.
Yes. For next year, we expect no changes.
Where does the recycling take place? Is a lot of it exported out of the country? Is there a good share recycled here in our own country?

Around 50% is in Ireland and 50% in facilities elsewhere in Europe. That is currently where we are at. We are meeting the recycling intake requirements of Irish recyclers in full. As they increase capacity, we will give them more.
How many recycle centres do we have in Ireland?
Three.

There are three in the country and as for the depots where the plastic is collected from farmers around the country, I must compliment the IFFPG on that. While it tries to get local as much as possible, I presume it has a good share of those depots throughout the country.
We have five contractors collecting on our behalf and 200 bring centres.
Sorry, will Mr. Moloney repeat that?

There are 200 bring centres scattered throughout the country, so there should be one within a reasonable distance of every farmer. We also provide a farmyard collection service for farmers who cannot make it to the bring centre.
That is good. They are my questions. I thank the witnesses.
Does any of the IFFPG plastic going for recycling go to Monaghan?
Yes, it does. There is a recycler there we supply.

Mr. Moloney will be aware, as it was in the newspapers, that the licence is to store 4,000 tonnes. I will not mention names, but it was in the newspapers and is public knowledge so I am not saying anything untold. Planning was refused for it to be able to go up to 20,000 tonnes. Did IFFPG send plastic there since that?
We supply it all the time. As I understand it, its permit is compliant.
Does Mr. Moloney know what tonnage is there? Is it inside the boundaries of 4,000 tonnes?
I have no idea. That is a matter for the recycler but none of the authorities have brought to our attention any problem with the plant.

My next question is for Ms Kiely and the Department. We try to encourage recycling everywhere. I ask Ms Kiely to look at it from this side for a moment. If I am an entrepreneur who decides to put in a system - someone in Clare is doing that at the moment and has put in a huge effort - the Department tries to encourage people to do these things. If I head off and put down my tanks, get my shredding machine and try to get it to green waste - amber is a problem - washed, cleaned and baled, I can get it to some facilities for little money. The Department is preventing people from being entrepreneurs because €286 per tonne is paid for that, but if I set up in my plant to do this and collect plastic, I am prevented from that. Should the Department not be looking outside the box to encourage more around the country - IFFPG provides a service - rather than stuff having to leave the country as amber waste with big problems. Loads that went out of the country through Antwerp had to come back. They are the facts. There is a lot of hassle in that. Instead of just doddling along, why do we not have a system or opportunity, for people who decide to set up a plant? Everything is about the importer. The Department said today that the person who sends it in is responsible for that plastic, end of story. These plants are tricky - let no one say they are not - and the volumes that can be got through are small. I have been to plants around the country that had great aspirations, but it is tricky stuff and the machinery is pretty complicated. The Department is now preventing people, like the outfit in Clare from getting the €286 per tonne that might make it viable. I have looked at what the outfit in Clare is doing. It is able to wash the plastic, get it baled and so on. It is well known that there are many more openings for it if it is that way. Why is the Department not prepared to think outside the box?
Can we let Ms Kiely answer that?
I am not familiar with the precise case the-----
I am talking about if I decided to do it in the morning.
I do not see how the scheme is preventing any of that happening.
How would I get the €286 per tonne?
The scheme is there-----

If I set up a plant recycling plastic, I will not be the importer. I will have nothing to do with it. If farmers bring the plastic to me, they will pay the €120 or whatever they get to me, but the €286 per tonne for when it comes into the country will not be paid to me. Is that not preventing me being an entrepreneur in that industry?

The scheme is open to any proposal from a domestic recycler. I do not see how that is a difficulty. If the Deputy is talking about the levy on the plastic at the point of purchase, that is how the producers meet their obligations-----
Yes, that is what I am talking about.

-----and they place it on the market. The producers have chosen under the regulations, as is their right, to set up a scheme, to organise for the payment of that levy into the scheme and organise the recycling in that way. It means all that plastic is collected and recycled successfully. The scheme would like to see more of it recycled in Ireland.

Would it not be a better system to encourage different things such as if on every bit of plastic that came in, the levy was paid like it is on other things? We pay carbon tax to the Government. The levy could be paid and whatever IFFPG does, it is paid; whatever Johnny down the road does with his recycling, as long as he has the numbers on every roll, he is paid. Why is there no thinking outside the box? This shop is closed to anyone who wants to set up a recycling business in Ireland because they will get €120 as against €286. The maths do not stack up. A place in the Netherlands is gone. If that goes outside the EU, under the green deal we cannot go there, so we need to look outside the box to try to encourage more people to find more ways to recycle. I cannot understand the Department's closed door on all this.
Is there a question?
Yes. Is the Department open to looking at something like I described?
As far as we are concerned, the scheme is meeting the objectives.

Yes, Ms Kiely should keep repeating herself. There is no point. We know that under the scheme that is there, whoever brings it in pays this levy. However, if I set up an industry that will provide employment, recycle plastic and do good for both farmers and our country, I will be left out of the €286 no matter what I do. Is that the way the Department wants to go on?
I think the Deputy is putting the €286 together with setting up-----

No, it is €286 per tonne for plastic coming into the country. That is it. It is €120 after that. That is what it is and the €120 is doubled because every tonne that comes in clean, goes out as two tonnes, so that is €240.

summary.i: Deputy Aindrias Moynihan resumed the Chair.

speech.p: The commercial undertaking is a matter for the IFFPG and if someone has a proposal to put together-----

No, hold on. IFFPG runs its own business. The officials are the Department of climate action and all that, so it is their Department. In fairness, the bottle scheme, as Deputy Aird said earlier, has been a good success. These are new ideas. However, if I decide I will be Mr. Recycler of Ireland, that I will set up a plant and do everything, all I get for every tonne I put in is to lose €286. That is some system if a country it talking about recycling. I advise the Department to think about what it is doing and think outside the box for entrepreneurs. What is going in Clare is small scale, but what the person has done to recycle is phenomenal.

I apologise for being in and out of the meeting. Going back to some of the figures mentioned, the cost of recycling 40,000 tonnes is €4.5 million, the cost per tonne to remove the recycling is €112.50, there are 24,000 tonnes in storage at the moment, and there will be roughly €3 million left at the end of the year. At the same rate as for the 40,000 tonnes, the 24,000 tonnes would cost €2.7 million. Mr. Moloney said we could use the money coming in next year but that will be for the product sold next year and it should not be used for this year's figures. Obviously it does not need to be, if the figures are correct.

It is better just to speak in aggregate terms. We will collect and recycle approximately 40,000 tonnes of waste this year.
