It will cost around €4.5 million to collect it and bale it and around €4.5 million to recycle it. At the end of the year we expect to have no more than 14,000 tonnes or 15,000 tonnes in our yards. In the early part of next year we will comfortably recycle it before we go out collecting again in April or May. Then the money will start flowing again. We are in a financially sound situation and it is important to state this, although we have no great excess of funding. We have enough funding to do what we are doing but we are not yet in a position where we could look at, for example, giving reductions to farmers and members. Maybe a few years down the line we will be able to do this.
The collection charges are used to recycle.
We have two sources of funding. There is the recycling levy and the collection charge. It goes into a kitty and we draw from that kitty to pay all of our costs. This is how we operate.

It seems to me that at the end of this year there will only be €300,000 left in the bank if the 24,000 tonnes in storage are recycled. This is what will be left over, using the figures based on 40,000 tonnes costing €4.5 million.

I would expect that at the end of the year, when we have recycled 40,000 tonnes and paid for collecting it, we will have somewhere between €2.5 million and €3 million in the bank. There will still be 14,000 tonnes or 15,000 tonnes to be recycled early in 2026. There is more than enough funding to do this and there will be money flowing through again from around May and June. If there is a concern about our finances, I want to make it clear that we are financially stable and sound.

I ask Mr. Moloney to speak to me little about the regulations on plastics coming down from the Six Counties. What are people required to do at the bring centres? Are they required to hand in receipts? Are receipts being forged? How is it that some might be sneaking in?

We have made a very big strong push to tighten it up this year. People are required to provide a valid label code, which they get when they purchase the plastic. They are also required to provide proof of purchase, such as an invoice or a receipt. When they come to the bring centre the contractor will check on the app whether the label code is valid, invalid or overused. The paperwork will also be checked. If the requirements are not met, the person risks being double charged. As my colleague, Ms O'Sullivan, said, if they can subsequently show us they did in fact buy levied product they get a refund. I am not saying the system is watertight. It is not watertight-----
But it will get better though.

It is getting tighter and it is getting better. It is making it more uncomfortable for farmers to buy unlevied plastic. This is what we are trying to do. We are trying to help the authorities to curb the illegal trade.
Of all of the tonnes of plastic that are sold, a certain amount is not brought back by farmers.
Yes.

Does Mr. Moloney think it is a case they hang on to it for two or three years? Perhaps a smaller farmer can store it at home. Will more regulations be coming into place? We all know most farmers will have this, unless they have pit silage or whatever. Will the Department come and investigate this?

We have to make it very clear that farmers are doing a magnificent job, with 100,000 of them engaging with the scheme. Over a three-year period, virtually everything put on the market for one year is collected and recycled. We have nearly a 100% recycling rate for the plastic our members put on the market. There is not an awful lot more we can expect of farmers. We would like to get those who are not recycling involved in recycling but the overwhelming majority of farmers are using the service. Most of them will use it each year and some of them on a two- or three-year cycle.
Mr. Moloney is saying 50% of the waste was recycled in Ireland.
Yes.
What is the difference between the cost of the recycling in Ireland compared to the cost of recycling at a European facility?
It is approximately the same. It can vary a little bit up and down. We require the Irish recyclers to operate in the same ballpark as the European recyclers. It is approximately the same.
That goes on a ship and is exported.
Yes.
And they can recycle it cheaper than us.
Not necessarily.
But there is an-----

The cost per tonne for us when we supply to recyclers is made up of transport and gate fees. The transport cost to Irish recyclers can be low but the gate fee can be high, whereas with European recyclers the transport costs tend to be high, for obvious reasons, and the gate fee is lower. They are approximately the same.

This is a big issue I have with the bottle and can return scheme. The whole idea of doing it is to do better for the environment but then we are shipping them out of the country. This is a contradiction in itself when it comes to the environment. Are we going to get to a stage where we can recycle all of it in Ireland? How far away does Mr. Moloney think this is?

Did I hear Mr. Moloney say earlier there is not a massive uptake on the recycled products? What is being made from it? I know there are stable doors and plastic fencing. Will there be a little bit of an incentive to get more people to use these products? I would suggest there should be an incentive for farmers who buy it back in as fence posts, stable doors or shed doors, so it is more economical to do it here and to have a centre in Ireland. We could do this and keep the products in Ireland.

At present, 50% is recycled in Ireland and we are meeting the intake requirements of these recyclers in full. We would love to see a situation where everything was recycled in Ireland, for obvious reasons. We are working with the recyclers, encouraging them to expand their plants, and go through planning and review processes, so they can take more in. The operating environment is quite difficult at present. This is because of world commodity prices and so the recyclate they produce, the finished product, is not commanding a high price at present. I hope that in time this will change. I also hope that some of the recyclers will produce a higher value pellet that can go into higher value products, which would be good for everybody. We would love to see some of the plastic we collect turned into a high value pellet by an Irish recycler, which would go back into Irish wrap, which would go back on the market. This would be a true circular economy. We are working with recyclers and our producers to try to bring this about. Most definitely we would love to see everything recycled in Ireland but the capacity just is not there at present.
Can Mr. Moloney see this changing? Is there a part the Government can play to incentivise people to try to get all of the recycling done in Ireland-----
I cannot speak for the Government-----
-----or maybe in Europe?

I know one of the recyclers in particular has ambitious plans to take in more material from us next year. This is the sort of thing that we welcome. We will give them as much as they can take, provided they can recycle it and they are some way commercially in the same ballpark as other recyclers. This is something we encourage and cajole inasmuch as we can but we have no direct control over it.

I have seen some of the recycled plastic products and they are extremely good. When they get a kick they can take a bit of shock, unlike timber which will snap. They are quite good and it would be nice to see it.

We have a recycler in west Clare who is doing something really nice. She is taking in plastic sheeting, sheeting from pit covers and fertiliser bags and turning it all into fence posts that are being sold back to farmers. That is the sort of thing we are trying to support and encourage. We want to see more of that.
Can I come in for a second round?
Yes. Before that, however, I have one more person who wants ask a few questions in the first round.
Work away.
There will be plenty of opportunities to speak.
I would like to go again.

I have a few questions myself. The IFFPG is required to carry a contingency of €3 million. Earlier, in response to Deputy Lawless, Mr. Moloney referred to a figure of €700,000. The accounts from last year suggest that there is €1.7 million in reserve.
Yes.
Where is the gap and what is the reserve?

It can be a bit confusing. If you look at our accounts, the reserve is total assets minus total liability, which is the truest reflection of the financial health of a company. We had €1.7 million in the reserve at the end of last year. We would expect that to maybe go back to €2.5 million or €3 million by the end of this year. Within that, we are setting up a contingency fund, which is money that is locked away and can only be accessed in exceptional circumstances with the co-operation of the Department. We expect that contingency fund to be at €700,000 at the end of the year. It can be a bit confusing but I hope that has explains it.
Would that €700,000 would be for the likes of clean-ups or whatever?

That would be for dealing with exceptional circumstances if they should come our way, as happened over the past number of years, for example, with the recycling market being extremely difficult or some other major global event that impacts how the company operates. It is there for the rainy day, shall we say.

There was a rainy day when it came to the situation in Leinster, as described by Deputy Aird earlier. There was a clean-up needed. Mr. Moloney is telling us that the plastics that are there did not come through his operation. What is the likelihood of a similar situation occurring elsewhere?
I can only speak for our yards. We take 100% responsibility for whatever-----
This would have been one of the IFFPG's yards.

That is true, but, as I said earlier, we would have taken responsibility for whatever we supplied into that yard. Of whatever we supplied into that yard, we got recycling certificates back from the contractor confirming it was recycled. However, there was material coming in from non-IFFPG sources too. What is left in the yard is not our responsibility.
Yes, but what I want to know what is the likelihood of that situation or something similar emerging in other places?

I was just going to say that with regard to our contractors, that situation will not happen because we have 100% responsibility for the plastic they collect. We own it at all points until it goes to the recycler. It will not happen with any yards that we have responsibility for.
With regard to the levy on the bale of wrap, the farmer pays up front. What is that levy based on?

It is based on giving us the majority of our funding through the recycling levy. Approximately 70% of our funding comes in from the recycling levy. The rest comes in from a weight-based collection charge from farmers.
How was the figure originally arrived at? As I understood, it was supposed to cover the cost of the operation.

If you go back a long time ago, it did. Maybe 25 years ago, the recycling levy covered the full cost of the operation. We have gone with a hybrid funding model, however, because we feel it leads to better quality plastic being delivered at the bring centres. We charge the farmer by weight and it gets the farmer thinking about the quality of the plastic he or she is delivering. That is why we have gone with that funding model. If we did not have a collection charge, we would have to substantially increase the recycling levy to make up for the loss of the collection charge. We feel that would have an impact on the quality of the plastic we collect.

I will return to the reserve. The IFFPG would have to go to the Department to get approval to eat into that reserve and that approval was forthcoming on one or two occasions. Would it have set out a plan on how quickly they were going to recover?

Yes, that is part of an ongoing conversation with the group. It has been such a dynamic situation in the past number of years. This year and last year have probably been a bit better, but when there were a lot of crosswinds, if you like, it was difficult for the scheme, and then it responded with proposals to put up the fees.
When is the reserve expected to be back at 100%?
It will probably take a couple of years yet, given the-----
Even though it is at €1.7 million now and it is expected that €700,000 to €800,000 will be put into a contingency.
The contingency fund is a ring-fenced account, so it can only be accessed in certain circumstances, as opposed to the surplus available to the scheme on an ongoing basis.
It is going to take a number of years.
It will, yes.

In the meantime, IFFPG is treading water. It has absorbed a number of shocks, and Mr. Moloney is telling us it is financially sound provided it is not going to be subjected to another shock in the next seven or eight years. It will be then before it will be back up again at €3 million.
No. We would expect, as was just mentioned, that maybe in a couple of years we would have €3 million ring-fenced.
A couple, as in two.
Yes, hopefully, and then we would have a surplus on top of that, which is an operating surplus over and above that.
Other than hope, has Mr. Moloney set a target?

It is very difficult. I would say within two years or so we would be hopeful. I have to say hopeful because things have been so chaotic over the past number of years. It is very hard to predict things with certainty.

I need to move to one other aspect of it. Where does the plastic go? Farmers load it in at the mart and they expect, having paid for it, that it is being recycled. Where is it going at present? Is it stockpiled in the different yards or where does it go?

There are what I would describe as comfortable amounts of material in our contractors' yards, but it is going to recyclers all the time. Some 50% goes to Irish recyclers and the other 50% goes to recyclers located elsewhere in Europe. At the moment, we are recycling around 40,000 tonnes per annum.
IFFPG has capacity for about 40,000 tonnes in the different yards.
Around 45,000, yes.
That means there is about a year's space.

Exactly. One of the recommendations of the IFAC review was that we should have something approximate to the equivalent of one year's storage in spare capacity. When we start our bring centres next-----
Mr. Moloney wants to be able to stockpile more.

No, ideally we do not want to be able to stockpile more but, if there is another big global event that really impacts the recycling market and we are left with no choice but to stockpile for a number of months, we want to have spare capacity.

There have been quite a number of references to the very successful plastic bottle levy. This thing is very much in contrast to it because if you are using the plastic bottle levy, you pay once. When you go back in with your bottle, you get money back. If you go in with your plastic for farming, you are being charged again in respect of it. It does not make sense that you would be paying again and again. Farmers feel very much aggrieved about this. It is very much like there is a system set up and the opportunity for an alternative system to compete with it is not there. You would have to have the plastics guys involved, and they are already involved in one particular organisation. The opportunity does not seem to be there for another company to come in, compete and provide better value for the farmer. It is almost like the farmer is very much a price taker in the whole thing. You can run a highly efficient organisation or an inefficient organisation, and the farmer will end up having to pick up the tab for it. It is really difficult for farmers to take that. They are very keen to have a highly efficient organisation on their own farms, and they expect it from their suppliers and customers as well.

I will respond to the references to the deposit and return scheme. The Department welcomes the positive reaction to that scheme. They are two entirely different markets. The plastic the Chair is talking about, from the plastic bottles, is polyethylene terephthalate, PET, and it has a positive market value.

When someone collects and recycles it, it has a value. It has a very high market value. Used silage wrap that is in a wet and mucky condition has a negative value because somebody else will have to be paid to deal with it. They are two entirely different types of material and two entirely different markets.

It is very difficult. That is one of the reasons a scheme like this has its challenges. At the same time, however, it provides security. Regardless of where the market goes in terms of it being attractive or unattractive to get involved in plastic recycling, there is a scheme that bears the responsibility and is answerable for how it collects, handles and manages the plastic throughout its life cycle. However, it is not out there in the market and necessarily available to all those who may be caught holding the plastic when the price drops dramatically and it is suddenly undesirable. The scheme offers security for the environmental and economic risk that kind of material carries. I know the group would like to come in on another point.

From my perspective, with farmers, the basic thing is that there is a service and there are local bring centres. One of the key asks is that there is a reliable service they know they can bring their plastic to and that here is full transparency on the cost and price, and when they are on. That is the biggest thing. We have spoken to our members on this. The biggest thing is that there is a local centre. There are 200 of these per year. The farmers know exactly where they are taking place and there is a weights system, so they know exactly what is going on.

When looking at this, it is very important to recognise that what we have in this country is very unusual. It is a massive success for the farmers who are participating in this scheme, and that should be recognised. Obviously, everyone would love to go back to the day when there was a value. With regard to the plastic, as Ms Kiely said, it is not a massive cost. There is a concern. We need to be looking at value markets or else the cost could potentially increase. It is a big issue. We need to be looking at markets to try to optimise so that-----
Costs could increase further than they have already increased.
Yes, we need to be looking at whether there are opportunities to do it domestically or at what innovations in technology are available to allow us to reduce the cost.

I have a question for Ms Kiely. It concerns the situation for those who are outside the IFFPG for one reason or another. On the previous occasion the group was in, a contractor gave evidence that their contract would cease that day. On average, if we tally it around the country, there are probably at least 10,000 tonnes of plastic that the levy is being paid on, but that is outside the IFFPG. The IFFPG has been paid €2.8 million. Would it not worry the Department if €2.8 million was paid in for stuff that the IFFPG had not handled, when it still had only €3 million in its account and there were 24,000 tonnes around the country? Would that not worry the Department?
Obviously, if the plastic is outside the system and is not treated-----
Hold on. It is paid for. Let us be clear about that. It is paid on the imports. Would that not worry the Department?
If the chain of responsibility has been broken-----

I am not talking about the chains. I am talking about the figures. If there are 10,000 tonnes that a levy has been paid on outside of it, and someone else picked up the money and there is still only €3 million in its account, along with 24,000 tonnes hanging around the country. Would that not worry the Department?
I do not know. Is the Deputy talking about a true situation or a hypothetical situation?
It is very simple what I am talking about. I am talking about a factual situation, not a hypothetical one. Would that not worry the Department?
If there is no safe way of dealing with the plastic, I would be worried, absolutely.

I propose that we write to the Minister to see if the statutory instrument can changed. I talked about entrepreneurs and different people. I ask the Chair to consider that we would write to the Minister to change the statutory instrument to try to facilitate options in this country whereby an entrepreneur who sets up a recycling plant would not be left out of getting this €280.

I second that proposal. The Department has created a closed loop that is preventing entrepreneurship and innovation in this space. Ms Kiely talked about a company that was producing chips to put back into the market and the circular economy, but the Department is preventing entrepreneurship in this space. That is what it is doing. In fairness, the Department has sort of shrugged its shoulders and said this is how it is. It is important that we open up this space to allow entrepreneurship to come in. The Department is preventing that. The levy is €286 a tonne, and no independent recycler could afford to lose that per tonne. I would like us to write to the Minister to change the statutory instrument in order to allow this to be opened up.
When is the contract up?
It is not a contract; it is an approval. The approval for the group expires at the end of this year.
At the end of 2025.
That is correct.
It is only right and proper that the Department would engage in a public advertising campaign, in the same way as for every other tendering process, to outline that this is open for applications.

I welcome the witnesses. I want to break this down into two segments. I want to talk to the IFFPG, but I will go first to the Department. At the outset, I apologise because I had to chair a meeting for the past hour that I could not get out of. I have just left there to be here. I hope I am not going to repeat what others have said because I was not tuned into this meeting.

I am a man who likes detail. I want to raise with the Department the fact that there was an opening statement by Ossian Smyth, the then Minister of State at the Department of the Environment, Climate and Communications with responsibility for communications and the circular economy, on 15 May 2024. I ask the witnesses to hold the date of that statement in their minds. The Department is back before us for this meeting today, Wednesday, 12 November 2025. We have had the two statements, and we might as well have had the same thing. There are sentences and sentences in today’s statement that are an exact copy of what was said a year ago. That is an important exercise that I would like the Department to look at tomorrow. As a matter of fact, I will give the witnesses the statements on their way out of today's meeting. It does not instil confidence in me that somebody could cut and paste the essence of a statement to the Houses of the Oireachtas. This is the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Agriculture and Food. I am disappointed about that, and I want that message to go back loud and clear to the Department and the Minister. The Department should not be represented in this way.

I thank Ms Kiely for agreeing to read the letter into the record. That allows us to make some reference to it because it is now on the public record of the Houses. Ms Kiely raised a number of issues that I thought were of concern. One of them was in relation to the concerns about the Border area. Ms Kiely and I are aware of the fluidity, the flexibility or - call it what you like - the porous nature of the Border between North and South. We would also be aware of anecdotal suggestions of inappropriate behaviour in relation to the movement of recyclable goods across the Border and how that is being policed. I want to flag that as a concern. It is an important point that I want Ms Kiely to confirm to me. I do my research before I come into these meetings. I want Ms Kiely to confirm to me what she knows of the concerns around that. It is an important point to make.
The devil is in the detail. It all hinges on the final paragraph of the statement that Ms Kiely read to the committee, which states:

The role of the Department is oversight of IFFPG’s adherence to the terms of its approval. A mid-term review of IFFPG’s current approval was concluded in 2024 and the Department requested IFFPG to undertake a series of actions relating to the board …

I can only presume these relate to the contingency fund, the importance of corporate governance and the suggestion or possible hint that there were irregularities or concerns in relation to those matters. Again, I want Ms Kiely to share with this committee on the record of this House what those concerns were.

We need to get to the bottom of this and drill down into the coded language used. It goes on to say that, "The Department is satisfied that [the] IFFPG is engaging positively". It gives the impression that the group was not engaging positively until now. Someone chose those words. Please remember I have had sight of last year's statement that was read into the record of the House by the Department. We are now being told that, "The Department is satisfied that [the] IFFPG is engaging positively with the outcomes of the review and continues to monitor same ... ". The Department clearly had concerns here and it is monitoring them. I want to know fairly quickly what those concerns were and how the monitoring is going. If it is not possible to do it now, the Department can write to the committee with additional information. I ask this question because I think it is an important point.

In relation to the licensing or tendering, call it what you will, I was struck when I read these papers the other day that there should be a public campaign around this matter. The public needs to know about it. We live in an open economy where competitiveness is important but transparency is also important. This is especially true for areas under the corporate governance codes for the private, semi-State and State sectors. I do not know how many people are geared up with the capacity to take on this project. This is another matter Ms Kiely will be privy to and she might share something with us on this point.

I am very pleased to see some of the major stakeholders who have a huge interest in and experience of this area. I engage with stakeholders all the time. I thank them for their engagement on this and other matters. It is great to see them here. I acknowledge their presence. Ms Kiely will be aware that the Irish Rural Association raised a number of serious issues, including legacy issues and the amount of leftover waste stockpiled, etc. What is Ms Kiely's view? Have things changed in a year? Is she aware of the stockpiling of waste anywhere in Ireland that has not gone through the processes? What has the Department done about it?

It must be remembered that the key message in the statement concerned the regulatory aspect. The Department was mandated with responsibility for regulation over this area. Ms Kiely might share with us what she knows and I will share with her what I sort of think I know. This is important. People are looking in. Farmers and the media are looking in. People look at "Oireachtas Report" and take great interest in the work of this committee. I am only a conduit to ask some of the hard questions. Hopefully, Ms Kiely will be able to give us some of the answers. I am also conscious of my time. The Irish Rural Association and other organisations have raised very serious concerns. Ms Kiely will be aware of them. They were discussed at previous meetings. She might just give this area some attention.

In terms of the opening statement of the IFFPG, I am encouraged when I read words like, "The IFFPG scheme clearly demonstrates that farmers are willing and able to effectively engage with ... environmental protection [incentives]". That is encouraging and really important. We need to get the message across that the people involved are not wasters and are not dumping stuff. They want to play a meaningful role. It is the case that it must be cost-competitive and there must be incentives and the farmers want the capacity to have the waste taken from farms. There are different methods and cost and time constraints in all of this. We must, though, play our role.

I think most of what I want to hear about is from the perspective of the Department and from Ms Kiely and Ms McCormack. They are charged with the policing of this area. I would like them to quickly touch on these issues. What are their concerns about the Border? What is their knowledge? I want them to tell me their knowledge of the stockpile of waste that has not been processed. I would like to know about the cost factor and the implications of that. Are there scams? Is the Department suspicious there may be scams in this sector? I am. I want to hear from Ms Kiely about the knowledge the Department has of these matters.
I thank Senator Boyhan.
There were a lot of questions to be addressed in a short time.
It is okay.
I am the last contributor and we have plenty of time. We are here until 6 p.m.
Yes. If Ms Kiely feels we are running out of time, there will be an opportunity for the Department to write back to the committee.
I did say that. I thank the Cathaoirleach.

A number of letters have been exchanged over the past while between the Department and the committee. A lot of detail has been provided, as requested. The opening statement is designed to be helpful but not to swamp the committee with a lot of original material. Hence it might have looked very similar to the previous one. The Senator is absolutely right in that the Department's role is in governance and oversight. Some of the recommendations we made as a result of the mid-term review did relate to governance. We were concerned that there were vacancies on the board. One of the matters addressed to the group was to ensure board members were recruited from the appropriate sectors and all vacancies were addressed and that any upcoming renewals and vacancies would be addressed. It was all addressed in the annual report for 2024 published this year. It has a wealth of information on corporate governance. Training was also provided for board members. Like any board, it is an ongoing situation and a developing context around governance. There are a lot of updated regulations and responsibilities and it is important boards are aware of them. That was all done and we were satisfied that it was addressed.

The contingency fund has been treated. Measures have been taken to ring-fence the funds available to the scheme separately. These are the funds to be put into the contingency fund. We are working with the scheme to ensure the fund is built up steadily over the coming years to an adequate level.

In terms of enforcement, there was a legacy of plastic in yards. We and waste enforcement authorities at the local authority level were concerned by it. Working with the scheme, they have addressed that issue to remove the excess plastic to be recycled. As we requested, they have organised a campaign to get that plastic out of yards and recycled in a timely manner. We are satisfied it has been completed to our satisfaction.

I think the Border was another concern of the Senator's. My understanding is that there is quite a differential between the price of plastic here and in the North. A large part of this difference relates to VAT. There is more than just the levy in the difference. People have quite an incentive to avoid paying that VAT. The enforcement authorities, the local authorities, the Revenue and the Garda are all available to the waste enforcement system and they have all been co-operating with the IFFPG to tackle that illegal activity. The group has taken steps to ensure farmers who have paid the levy are also in a position to produce a code at the time of collection to ensure no illegal material is coming into the system. That costs everybody more money and drives up expenses. Were they all the concerns the Senator had? Was there anything else?
Can I have a minute to come back in?
Go ahead.

I thank Ms Kiely. She has dealt with the points I made but she has not really got into the specifics. I am going to be very quick. It has not been confirmed that all the waste in yards has been cleared. Ms Kiely is saying she is satisfied it is happening.
They are not all cleared, no.

Right, but I wanted to hear that. I expected Ms Kiely to come in and tell me today the level of the problem that exists today. I do not want to hear about a plan, trajectory, a road or how many yards are involved. I am just going to flag this. Turning to the VAT issue, the Revenue is involved. Is Ms Kiely aware if Revenue is actively involved currently in relation to matters around this issue?
My understanding is that it has been in recent months.
It has been in recent months. That is grand. An Garda Síochána is involved. Can Ms Kiely tell me she has been engaging in the past few months with An Garda Síochána in relation to these matters?
That would be for the enforcement authorities to do and the Garda Síochána is available.
Is Ms Kiely aware of it?
I do know that the Garda has been directly involved in this instance.
Whether it is directly or indirectly, would Ms Kiely be aware of it? She should be aware of it.
I am not necessarily-----
Her Department should be aware of it.
It is not a regulatory matter for the Department. It is a matter for the local authorities.

Surely, down the corridor or up the back stairs, someone would tell Ms Kiely they know the Garda or the Revenue, the big boys, are on the case here, there are problems, they have not been sorted out and they are coming at the Department. People do not mess with the Revenue or An Garda Síochána. These are the enforcement agencies if there are issues around illegality, as Ms Kiely suggested.

I will finish by saying that I will be making a further call in this regard. Indeed, I have a number of questions in my head. I will go up to my office and type them out now, so they will come Ms Kiely's way in a few days. The issue of the involvement of An Garda Síochána will be among them, and rightly so, if there is illegality.

If there are issues about avoidance of tax, or the VAT rates, North and South, Revenue should be on that case too. We have got to clean up our act, literally, excuse the pun. I was not aware of what I have been told today that there are yards full of stuff that has not been processed.
No, they are not full of stuff, it is-----
Plastics.
Yes.
It is about farm management-----
Can I just finish with Ms Kiely? What are the yards full of?

I said at the beginning that at the end of September there was about 24,000 tonnes, so it is a cycle of filling yards and emptying yards. I am sure there is hardly a time of the year when yards do not have some material in them. At any point in time, there will be plastic. It is within the permitted provisions of the contractors' environmental licensing that they may hold material in the yards, so there is nothing wrong with material being in the yards.
Is Ms Kiely satisfied that everything is in full compliance and there is nothing irregular or illegal in any part of the sector?
I have no reports of any illegal activity.
Can Ms Kiely say that on behalf of the Department?
Yes, I would be confident.
Would Ms Kiely be reasonably confident or confident?
I would be very confident.
Okay, well say that so. I need reassurances, as does the public.

I just want to reiterate what Ms Kiely was saying. We collect the material typically between April and around October, so the yards are quite full then. Then onwards until April of the next year we collect very little, so we empty them out. We are very comfortable with the volume of material that is currently in our contractors' yards. We expect to have no more than 7,000 tonnes or 8,000 tonnes in our contractors' yards when they head out next April and May with the spring centre programme. The capacity for our contractors is 45,000 tonnes, so there is a lot of spare capacity. We do not want to fill up the yards but it is good to have so much extra capacity. As I said, we are comfortable with where things are at in the yards at the moment.
Is Mr. Moloney happy with how this new service agreement contract is going? Is he keen to keep going and be involved or does he know of other stakeholders that may wish to express an interest?

I have no idea about other stakeholders. They have the opportunity at any time to get an application in to the Department if they want to become a competing scheme but we are happy with the process that is under way with the Department in terms of the current approval renewal process.
Is Mr. Moloney is happy with the progress being made to date?
Yes, we are.

Sin deireadh na gceisteanna, tar éis plé suimiúil. Mo buíochas leis na bhfinnéithe. On behalf of the committee, I thank the witnesses for their presentation and their answers. That concludes the business of the committee and, as there is no further matter for discussion, the committee stands adjourned.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 5.53 p.m. until 3.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 19 November 2025.
